A certain rustic vigour of life, breezy freshness, as of the Cheviot hills;Range of hills extending NE to SW along the English-Scottish border, described by Story in “The Hills of my Birth-place“ (1837): “The hills of my birth-place I gazed on once more! / And Cheviot—their Monarch—sublime as of yore, / With the snow for his mantle, the cloud for his crown, / On the white vales beneath him looked royally down!“ (106). a kindly healthiness of soul breathes every where out of the book. No one that reads it, I should think, but will feel himself the better for its influences. I can honestly wish success to it; and to its author, peace and comfort for the days and years that remain. With many thanks and regards, I remain, yours sincerely, T. Carlyle.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 2 Nov. Addr: 25 Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. MS: NLS 552.146. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: I forgot to ask last night, How you were off for time at present? Perhaps driven, almost like the rest of us? In which case, never mind what is to follow here.

The fact is, vol xii of the “Works“TC is referring to Chartism and Past and Present (pbd. in one vol.); see TC to JN, 5 Nov., but Latter-Day Pamphlets was the 12th vol. to be pbd., Chartism and Past and Present the 13th. needs Summary and Index, like what you did for Lr Day Pamphlets (to be ready, say, in 6 weeks): if you have time, you will do it better than another;—but if you have not, it must take such an artist as it can get. Tell me, please. For there is now no time to be lost.
I am just about opening your late Packet,—by candle light,—with a shudder!

ps.p: Chelsea, 2 Novr, 1857—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 2 Nov. MS: NLS 516.48. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: I have not forgotten you; farther than ever from that. I daily eat of your bounty, and with much more thankfulness than you might fancy by my silence. That dainty Package, it was very kind of you, and very “spirited“: I am only sorry you shd have had such bother:—but indeed there is no good thing to be done on other terms. I am pleasantly called home into loving circles by these Gifts; and that is what you intended with them.

But ever since that Box came, I have been so driven as you never saw or cd imagine; worse than ever just about this time. It has lasted now above twelve-months, life of a hare before hounds;—and there is still a long course ahead! However, if I can hold out till May next, the First PartOf Frederick. will be done (2 thick Volumes then): and I shall fairly get to some rest again. A long effectual spell of rest; as far from this tremendous Babel and its noises as I can get,—and till I am quite tired of resting! We are just getting out of the First Vol. now;—in fact, the back of the thing is broken, were I rid of this immediate coil of confusions. Courage!—

Jane keeps up; very weakly; but takes no cold yet, and manages endurably in the matter of sleep. I too seem to be about my usual state,—thanks chiefly to my Horse, I think. Nobody can be more regular and diligent.

The good Jim must not think of London and me;Her eldest son James (“Jamie“) Aitken. Presumably he had expressed an interest in helping TC with his work. He had been employed as a clerk in Glasgow, 1853 (see 28:315TC to JCA, 18 Nov. 1853) but had left owing to unexplained trouble, after which TC and John A. Carlyle had tried to help him find other employment (see 29:63TC to JAC, 11 April 1854, 185–86TC to JAC, 4 Nov. 1854, and 190TC to DH, 4 Nov. 1854). He returned home to Dumfries, Nov. 1854 (see 29:205TC to JF, [22 Nov. 1854]), but was working in Glasgow again by mid-Feb. 1855 (see 29:266TC to JCA, 16 Feb. 1855). TC had advised him to go back to his old employers, Liepmann & Lehmann, commission merchants (see 29:236TC to JCA, 12 Jan. 1855), but by lateAug. 1855, he was working for Roxburgh, Richardson & Co., insurance, shipbrokers, and general agents, 7 Royal Exchange Pl., Glasgow, and living in new lodgings at Killermont St. (see Jean Carlyle Aitken to TC, 25 Aug. 1855; MS: NLS 1775B.166). At the end of Feb. 1857, John A. Carlyle enlisted the help of James Carlyle, James and Isabella’s son, even though the two cousins apparently did not get on (see 29:111–12TC to JCA, 6 June 1854). John wrote to James Carlyle, 2 March 1857, thanking him “for the pains you took on Saturday at my request“ and saying that he had written that day to Mr. Stevenson (possibly William Stevenson, commission agent and house factor of 9 Cambridge St., Glasgow, or William Stevenson & Sons, cotton spinners, S Exchange Court, 77 Queen St. [see 28:236TC to JACA, 29 July 1853]), James Carlyle’s employer, regarding the possible employment of James Aitken: “You seem to me to take a most reasonable view of the matter, & I think you went as far as you could in the way of indirect advice. … I am perfectly sure that you will never repent the decision you have taken for your dear mother’s sake. … I have told Mr S that you will be ready to answer any questions you can respecting your cousin“ (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). James Aitken appears not to have been employed by Stevenson; see TC to JCA, 10 Feb. 1858. he cannot be of the least
use here;—and at any rate I would by no means lead him away from his right pursuit. Let him hold on steadily: he is a really good lad (so far as I can construe him); and he need not doubt good is ahead of him, if he persevere. The other day a wretched Glasgow ClerkUnidentified. “intent on Literature“ &c called (not admitted), then wrote;—I subjoin his Note; whh burn, and say nothing to Jim of it. Love to all.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 5 Nov. Addr: 25 Oakley Villas, Adelaide Rd. / Haverstock Hill. MS: NLS 552.147. Hitherto unpbd. Final two lines are written on an enclosed piece of paper.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: Many thanks for your readiness;—always ready! Heroes & Sartor are now nearly thro’ the Press, Lr Day Pamphlets just going thither; the only vol. left is Chartism with Past & Prest.— I have, this moment, seen Larkin; who, after computation, thinks he can suffice for that volume too, on his own strength: so we will let him go ahead; and you are let off again,—quitte pour la peur [escape with a fright]; tho’ I do not think it was a ‘fear’ to you, either.

Here is a little Memorial I had in the Clip waiting for you; I send it, tho’ no other is yet there. It means that you will call at the Museum some day (no hurry); get the right Title of that curious little Book (whh I have read there: Letters from Bender &cAnecdotes du séjour du roi de Suède à Bender, ou Lettres de M. le Baron de Fabrice pour servir d’éclaircissement à l’histoire de Charles XII (Hamburg, 1760). Friedrich Ernst von Fabrice (1683–1750), envoy from Holstein to Charles XII of Sweden (1682–1721), with whom he spent long periods in Bender, Moldavia, between June 1710 and Aug. 1713; see Works 13:106–7.); and give said Title (‘p. 37 of Ms Book VI,’ being marked it upon it)Thus in MS. to Robson the Printer, who will insert it at the place.

ps.p: abt Charles XII / Letters of Fabrice / Title (Year, place, size) wanted in p. 37 of Ms.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-DD, 5 Nov. MS: Hilles. Pbd: Davidson, Memories 306–9.
div3.head: JWC TO DAVID DAVIDSON

docBody.p: and a furious protestant demonstration, on the part of Chelsea Boys, going on, in shape of squibs and rockets.)Guy Fawkes Day (Bonfire Night) celebrated the arrest of Guy Fawkes (1570–1606), a Roman Catholic and most famous of a group of conspirators who plotted to blow up Parliament in reprisal for the increased persecution of Roman Catholics under James VI and I (1566–1625). In the days before 5 Nov., children traditionally push an effigy of Guy Fawkes through the streets shouting, “Penny for the guy,“ and collect money to buy fireworks; the effigy is burned on a bonfire, 5 Nov. The occasion was probably more significant in 1857 because of the riots in Belfast between Catholics and Protestants, which began 23 Sept. and lasted a fortnight, resulting in a govt. commission of enquiry.

My dear Major Davidson. In the first place; thanks for your letter from the bottom of my heart! Reading it was like hearing music from one’s far home in a strange Land! I paid it the compliment of crying over it; what more could I do?— It is curious that, beside you, I always feel like to cry, even when I am laughing! and you are the only man that gives me, or ever gave me that inclination! Is it a good influence that, or a bad? I should say good, at the present date any how; for softness is not the quality a woman of my years is apt to carry too far; there is more tendency to become hard as the nether millstone; But let me keep out of metaphysics!

Do you know I was getting sadly afraid that you had abandoned the “hope“ of writing to me. But dont suppose the message about MaryMary Jeffreys. was a woman’s wile to quicken your “hope.“ I really was very anxious about the good old Soul, both for her own sake and your Aunt’s.Janet Davidson. Many a Peeress would have been less missed than that pattern Maid-of-all work! Her farewell words to me were often in my ears during the days I fancied her in danger; “ye’ll find us aye here, while we’re to the fore; but it’s no lang we can expeck to get bided noo!“See 32:197JWC to TC, [23 July]. The idea of her mistress and she being parted even in Death seemed to have no place in her head! Miss Jess Donaldson too wrote to me of her recovery, which was like her kindness. I have got a sketch of Sunny Bank framed and hung up opposite my bed;JWC had wanted a sketch of Sunny Bank in 1855; see 30 [29]:240JWC to JDO, 19 Jan. 1855. on the same principle that Ruskin has every night one or other of his splendid collection of Turner pictures placed on a chair at his bed-foot; that he “may have something spirit-stirring to open his eyes on, the first
thing, in the morning“!See 31:37–38JWC to WA, 23 Feb. [1856]; J. M. W. Turner (1775–1851; ODNB); Ruskin owned many Turner paintings and acted as administrator of his estate (rather than executor).— People have such different notions about what is spirit-stirring!—I have also brought back with me a clever drawing of the Nungate Bridge,Ancient three-arched bridge over the river Tyne, Haddington; see also Carlyle, Reminiscences 43 and 69. and the block of stone & mortar for the Boys to play at Ball on—which I would not exchange for any Turner I ever beheld! You would be amused—and, being you, I dare say you would be touched, to see my picture gallery!—representations, better or worse (mostly worse) of places and people, all out of or associated with “dear old Long ago“— Will you make me a drawing of your house“Woodcroft“; see Memories 304. when it is finished? or will you send me your photograph? You shall have a beautiful one of Mr Carlyle in return for it!

The MackenziesHelen and Colin Mackenzie. set out for India, via Brussels, a fortnight after my return; but they were with us three evenings. Both seemed in brave, composed spirits; tho the Indian business looked black enough just then! He meant to present himself at once to Lord Canning and ask to be sent on whatever service was most arduous. My Husband gave him a letter of most emphatic recommendation to Colin Campbell. We talked of you and your wife; and I think the right ears of you both must have rung with it!

Sir Colin writes that “if there was any nonsense in the english newspapers about Lord Canning and he not drawing well together, no word of it was to be believed; for nothing could exceed the kindness, and furtherance in every way, which he had been met with by both Lord and Lady Canning.“Lord Canning had been accused of being too lenient on the mutineers after his “Resolution,“ 31 July, which distinguished between sepoys from regiments that had committed bloodshed and those who were unarmed and innocent. Public opinion was firmly against “Clemency Canning,“ particularly following the capture of Delhi, 20 Sept., but Campbell agreed that restraint was vital to gaining the support of the Indian population. In a letter to Lady Canning, 22 Oct., the queen welcomed the news that Sir Colin supported Canning’s policy, and “does not share that indiscriminate dislike of all brown skins which is very unjust—for the Inhabitants have, it appears, taken no part in this purely Military Revolution—& while summary punishment must alas! be dealt out to the mutinous sepoys—I trust he will see that great forebearance is shown towards the innocent & that women & children will not be touched by Christian soldiers“ (quot. in Virginia Surtees, Charlotte Canning: Lady-in-Waiting to Queen Victoria and Wife of the first Viceroy of India, 1817–1861 [1975] 244). He says too that he has “a dreadful quantity of writing to do“—writing not being quite so easy for Colin as fighting! And so his bosom-friend Colonel SterlingFrances M. Brookfield wrote that friends tried to persuade JWC to mend her quarrel with Anthony Sterling before he left for India. Reluctantly she agreed and allowed him to call: “But Mrs. Carlyle soon after appeared at our house, and the expression of her countenance was ominous as she entered the room. ‘I have come to thank you,’ she said, in an ironical tone, ‘not, as you may expect, for having induced me to change my purpose, but I thank you for having taught me a lesson—never to try to make peace between those who have resolved to quarrel.’“ She explained that Sterling had brought her, “the most sensitive and superstitious of women, … the headgear that he had taken from the body of a dead Highlander in the Crimean War, and asked me to take care of it for him. Can you imagine anything which could better prove how little he understands me? All is over between us. It is worse than it was before.“ Sterling called again, and, after he had left for India, JWC said that he had made up for his earlier insensitivity by bringing her an old tea caddy that had belonged to his mother: “ ‘He said he believed I was the only human being now living who would value it, for his mother’s sake. …’ And as she spoke she burst into tears“ (“Some Reminiscences of Jane Welsh Carlyle,“ Temple Bar 69 [Oct. 1883]: 232). sailed yesterday
morning, “to take some of the writing off him poor Fellow!“— For the rest, it is Sir Colin’s idea, that Delhi once taken, there will be little more fighting; but that the Army will have to transform itself into a great Police Force.—

When are you coming to London again? They have made fine broad walks in the HospitalChelsea Hospital for old and disabled soldiers. park, and put beautiful live sheep in it; and there are seats to sit down, and rest, and talk; only there is no ‘gardener’s house’ to take refuge in from thunder showers!— I should have thanked you for your letter before today; had not a girl called Georgiana Craik had the smallpox some thirteen years ago!Her smallpox was probably in 1842, at the time of the death of her sister Isabella, who d. from it; see 15:221JWC to JW, [8 Dec. 1842]. a case of Tenterden Steeple causing the encroachment of Godwin Sands!See 9:250JWC to TC, [17 July 1837]. But—if you remember—there was discovered a good many years ago a real connexion of cause and effect between the Steeple and the Sands! So is there between little Miss Craik’s smallpox and my delay in writing. The smallpox made a very pretty girl into a very plain one; and the consciousness of her spoiled looks drove the girl’s exuberant young Life all inward where it has raged and eratedPresumably for “aerated.“ under a shy embarrassed, self-conscious exterior, till finally, after thirteen years, it has burst out in a passionate, all-for-love three-volume novel!Riverston, 3 vols. (1857); see 32:141JWC to GLC, 5 May. Which novel having been presented to me by the young Authoress, I was bound in common politeness, not to say kindness, to write her a letter of acknowledgement. But what to say, that would not hurt her feelings, and at the same time not hurt my own conscience, was a difficulty! The Book is “thrilling“ “enchaining“ “absorbing“—all a novel needs to be in interest; but to have written even “a “successful“ novel is a fault as well as a misfortune for a young Lady, I think; and, given this persuasion to be expressed in delicate, unwounding terms, and no such terms suggesting themselves, I had, day after day, written “5 Cheyne Row“ at the top of a sheet, and then, not “my dear Georgiana“; but “my dear somebody else“; on the quite
“voluntary principle“!Coterie speech; see 26:158JWC to TC, [7 Sept. 1851]. Till at last, ashamed of my off-putting, I took a solemn engagement with myself that I wouldn’t write to man woman or child, till that other letter was dispatched!Georgiana Craik replied, 4 Nov., from Belfast: “It was so good of you to write me that long, kind, delightful letter! You do not know how much pleasure it gave me—how glad and grateful I am for it. I will never either lose it or forget it, but keep it amongst the letters that I love best, and value most.—Do you know I never was afraid of you reading my book. Perhaps I ought to have been—Mary was—and indeed my want of fear did not come from belief that the book was good. It only came from belief in you, and all your goodness to me; for you have never been anything but so kind to me from the time I was a child, and I could not help trusting in you, and believing that, even if you were utterly to condemn my book, you would do it tenderly. I am so glad that I was right: I am so glad that, instead of condemning, you can tell me that you took some interest in my story.“ Jewsbury reviewed it kindly but concluded that “Miss Craik … has the power to do something far better than ‘Riverston,’ and we shall look with interest for her next work“ (Athenaeum, 19 Dec.). So now you see how Georgiana Craik’s smallpox thirteen years ago prevented your getting a speedier answer!

It is close, heavy, sloppy weather, giving one the feeling of being weltering in Train oil!— I would rather be at Morningside by a great deal; ceteris paribus [other things being equal]. I should be thankful however that I keep on foot. I do just that, and no more. It will be better with me perhaps when we are out of this “gloomy month of November, in which (according to some French Writer) the people of England hang and drown themselves.“Coterie speech; see 30:119TC to JAC, 19 Nov. 1855. Will you give my love—to your wife; and a kiss to that darling little BoyEither Henry, aged 6, or David, aged 3. who burst out laughing at me! And will you “hope to write“ to me now and then?— You may do it under the account of “time devoted to charitable purposes“—

closer.salute: And so goodby and all blessing on you and your belongings!

docBody.name: Jane Welsh Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 13 [12] Nov. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas, Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. PM: 12 Nov. 1857. MS: NLS 552.148. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdates the letter, as the PM is 12 Nov.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p:
They have taken my Preuss (big Lebensgeschichte 5 voll.)The London Lib. had recalled Johann David Erdmann Preuss, Friedrich der Grosse: eine Lebensgeschichte, 4 vols. (Berlin, 1832–1834) and Urkundenbuch zu die Lebensgeschichte (Berlin, 1832–1834); see Works 12:324 and London Lib. catalog (1914). TC apparently bought a later edn., Die Lebensgeschichte des grossen Königs Friedrich von Preussen, 2 vols. (Berlin, 1837): HCC. from me; whh was an unkind cut: however, we must do without, for a 6 or 7 weeks. I think
this, following, is the only instance in which I shall indispensably want a glance into the blockhead.

In the War of 1734 (it will be early in vol 1), Friedh, out on a reconnoitring party one day, is vigorously fired-upon (across the Rhine I almost think?), and does not wince in the least. There is in Preuss some vague Excerpt from somebody or other giving record of this.See Works 14:123–24. Dead, dull, vague as I remember; but I must have it,—and any specification (of when, where, how &c) that is attainable by human industry versus human indolence and dulness!—

If you were to look into the Museum, tomorrow, next day, you could get me this Excerpt, and perhaps hunt it (there) into something of definiteness. I remember it merely as a detached despicable rag, hanging upon nothing,—tho’ I have read it many times.

Here is the first movement I have experienced in the Tauchnitz matterChristian Bernhard Tauchnitz was to publish the first German edn. in English of vols. 1 and 2 of Frederick (Leipzig, 1858); see 32:138TC to JN, 1 May. from Covent-Garden quarter;I.e., Williams & Norgate, booksellers, 14 Henrietta St., Covent Garden; see 32:138TC to JN, 1 May. the ansr was, “Print at £50 per volume, or leave the thing unprinted“; for a year or two I wish to hear no farther account of it on other terms.— You may burn Wm’s & Norgate’s letter.
Sunday Evg we shall partly expect, then?

ps.p: I may as well enclose Chapman’s Letter too; I don’t want it again either.

div3.sourceNote: TC-EC, 13 Nov. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO EDWARD CHAPMAN

docBody.p: I enclose you a Note of the Title;For Frederick. It was advertised as History of Friedrich the Second, King of Prussia, called Fredrick the Great in the Athenaeum, 14 Nov. (see 32:218Chapman & Hall’s Advertisements); its title became History of Friedrich II. of Prussia, called Frederick the Great; see Tarr 166. the best I have been able to contrive, after many times surveying the difficulties of it in past months. The great thing is to be quite intelligible. I leave it with you in this stage.

I depend upon you altogether for the American negociation; and shall not stir in it myself;—not doubting you will vanquish for me in it, so far as needful.For earlier correspondence with Chapman about the American publication of Frederick, see 32:2TC to [FC], 2 Oct. 1856.

With the German affair,Concerning the German publication of Frederick in English and in trans. I am sorry to answer, there seems nothing to be done. The “right of translation“ I gave away, long since, to a Mr Neuberg here (who has been extremely useful to me): he ‘sold’ it to the Court-Publishers (Decker at Berlin) for the magnificent sum of nothing at all (such being the Decker view of it); and he has the Translation mostly done,The first two vols. of Frederick, trans. into German by Neuberg, Geschichte Friedrichs II. von Preussen genannt Friedrich der Grosse (Berlin, 1858–59), were pbd. by R. Decker. I believe,—goes on along with Robson thro’ it.

Then as to, Tauchnitz and reprinting the Book in Germany, Tauchnitz wrote to me about that a long time ago; I made Neuberg answer him “£50 a volume,“ and correspond with him; Tauchnitz (according to Neuberg’s report) professed himself ready or about ready,—“wd employ Wm’s & Norgate to make the bargain with me.“ Wm’s & Norgate seem to have taken up the notion, and given it to him, that they cd have the article for half-price; they have been obliquely trying me on those terms, and have now written formally to you.— The answer, I consider, in these circumstances ought to be: If Herr Tauchnitz does not like the Book at £50 per volume (money down when he gets the sheets), let it remain unprinted,—we are in no hurry abt it!See TC to JN, 13 [12] Nov.— The fact is, nothing runs away with the reprinting there, as is the fatal case in America.Where it might be printed without authority from or payment to TC; cf. 32:39–40TC to RWE, 2 Dec. 1856. And we can let the Wms & Norgate obliging speculation take the air for a while.

I was sorry indeed to hear from Mr Tait that the Photograph Engravers are somehow out of gear! I think it will be a real loss if we cannot get that Frontispiece to vol 1;The frontispiece to vol. 1, “The Little Drummer,“ was engraved by Francis Holl (1815–1884; ODNB) from Lord Ashburton’s copy of Antoine Pesne’s original at Charlottenburg; see 29:74TC to JN, 28 April 1854, and Works 12:opp. 370; see also 31:123TC to RST, 15 July 1856, and 147TC to RST, 1 Aug. 1856. and in a perfect conditn it must be or not at all:—I declare I shd almost vote for Photographs rather than miss.— Pray exert your best skill; and especially let no time be lost.

I have been examining Portraits of F’s Father & Mother (Frontispiece to Vol II, whh would be very useful too, if we cd get them good):The frontispiece to vol. 2 was of Friedrich Wilhelm, from Pesne’s engraving; see Works 13:frontispiece. I have seen some tolerable; and have written to Berlin for a better choice. The faithfullest Engraver you can think of: Holl I did not think first-rate in the old Cromwell caseFor Samuel Cooper’s miniature of Cromwell, engraved by Holl, see 20:37TC to MAC, 31 Oct. 1845, and Works 6:frontispiece.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord A[LOA], 15 Nov. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LORD ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I have somewhat lost the correct track of you lately: Lady Sandwich told me you were across in Scotland; had been at Inverary;Inverary Castle, 18th-cent. building on the NW bank of Loch Fyne, Argyll, the seat of George Douglas Campbell (1823–1900; ODNB), 8th duke of Argyll, Whig politician, postmaster gen., 1855–1858; m., 1844, Elizabeth, b. Sutherland-Leveson-Gower (1824–78). had breakfasted with her big GraceAnne Colquhoun, b. Cuninghame (d. 1874), dowager duchess of Argyll; 3d wife, m. 1831, of John Douglas Edward Henry Campbell (1777–1847), 7th duke of Argyll. one morning; seen “Le plus vaillant [the most valiant]“ and his Spouse,Both unidentified. of whom I used to hear in Edinr long ago:— I vaguely fancy you may be with Stirling;William Stirling of Keir, about 4 mi. N of Stirling. somewhere or other this will come to hand, and remind you that I am still alive. For the last several weeks I have been quite unusually hunted: proof-sheets numerous and, beyond the average, abstruse; &c &c: in fact I never in my life had such time as for the last year; and no such job, I often think, was ever laid upon a reasonable creature, not naturally concerned with it. In truth, it has quite broken my heart, it and its adjuncts; and I pass the saddest heavy-laden days; and in grim fact, often feel to myself as if I never shd get thro’ it alive,—not to speak of its being of the least worth to me or others; when got thro’! The Arithmetical truth is, however, we are getting into the actual Second Volume; and if I can hold out till about May next, I shall have this Instalment off my hands,—and a long spell of rest fairly ahead of me.

Lady Sandwich, good old Lady-Mother, is tolerably well; cheery and talky, when I called, the other evening. My Wife takes rather less kindly, I doubt, to the winter weather; however, she too is still afoot, and better than last year this time. I have seen, as it were, nobody; speak to nobody, except to the Prussian Mud-demons and my Horse.— Alfred Tennyson & Wife turned up one day, escorted by Mrs Cameron:Julia Margaret Cameron, b. Pattle (1815–79; ODNB), artist and later a famous photographer, living at Putney, borough of Wandsworth, W London, S of the Thames; she met the Tennysons shortly after their marriage, 1850, and they became close friends. the melodious man was kind but inarticulate; was gravitating willingly homewards from his Northern gaieties. Twisletons were here one night; the young Boston Sister has a Boston Husband with her this time,—on their marriage journey;Elisabeth, b. Dwight (1830–1901) m., 1857, James Elliot Cabot (1821–1903); he had studied law and architecture but did not practice either; friend, future literary executor, and official biographer of Emerson. Elisabeth Dwight had spent a year with the Twisletons, Oct. 1855 to Oct. 1855; see 30:xix–xx30:introduction, 114JWC to LA, 14 Nov. 1855, and 144TC to JCA, 23 Dec. 1855. bound “to Italy,“ and generally to the land of Promise: a likely enough young pair. Twn is rather
clear as to the “impossibility“ of ever colonising India, “such is the cheapness of labour“ &c &c: in which notions I shall be glad to find you totally dissent from him: in fact, if we cannot keep a million or two of native white men on the high lands of India (as they do in Cuba among the Africans down below),Spain began its conquest of Cuba, 1511, and the slave trade to Cuba began, 1523; slavery was not abolished there until 1886. it is not visible to me how we shall ever do good there.

A terrible “money-panic“ you must have heard of;Property and railway stock speculation caused a financial crisis in the U.S., late summer, with banks and commercial houses being suspended as a result. By mid-Nov., the effects of the crisis were felt in England and Scotland. To avert the panic caused by the failure of several joint-stock banks and large commercial houses, the Bank of England, with the approval of the govt., suspended the gold standard, violating the Bank Charter Act of 1844. The Examiner reported, 14 Nov., that the “financial and commercial embarrassments of the United States have told in this country with rapid and almost unexampled severity, and the failures of the week have been heavy and numerous.“ The Times warned, 20 Nov.: “While we have been increasing our promises to pay in gold, the stock of gold on which these promises are based has been steadily diminishing. All will see that this inverse process must have certain limits, and that if those limits were reached, national suspension would be the result.“ John A. Carlyle wrote, 3 Nov.: “[W]e have had an agitation about the solvency of the Western Bank of Scotland, in which I have more than half of my money & Jamie all his. There was a run at the Head-office in Glasgow; but gold enough was found to meet every demand, & the panic has now ceased, & our local Agents have been purchasing shares largely for themselves. Failures in the United States, & a false idea that the Western Bank was too deeply involved in them, caused the panic. ‘John Jardine the carrier’ took out his money some £50 from the Ecclefechan Branch & ‘Tom Cavel of the Turfrig’ got three one pound notes of the Western Bank hurriedly exchanged for other notes; & that was the extent of our panic in Ecclefn.“ But Jess Donaldson wrote, 30 Dec.: “The Bank failures are my all absorbing subject.“ Ellen Twisleton wrote to an English friend from Italy, 25 March 1858, that all the letters from her family in the U.S. “have been so sad and dispiriting. … [I]n a few weeks my eldest sister, my brother and my uncle … lost nine-tenths of all they had … such was the suddenness of the crash, that they hardly yet know where they stand. … My brother saved me personally from actual loss, but nothing could prevent our feeling the great depreciation of all investments this year“ (Letters of the Hon. Mrs. Edward Twisleton Written to Her Family 1852–1862 [1928] 292–93). but, I suppose and hope, have nothing to do with,—clear above it, as I am clear below it. If the sum of all the “Commercial Madness“ in America and Europe (every piece of nonsense and unveracity done by a trading man) is getting itself liquidated in this manner, we may fancy it can be no slight operation!— — I am at the bottom of my Paper; and such a sheaf of Proofs lie waiting me, I must not take another sheet. We hope you will be home soon: that is the burden of the song!Cf. line 5 of “The Miller of Dee,“ Isaac Bickerstaffe, Love in a Village (1765). I rode by Streatham this afternoon,—sad remembrances exciting me there; sad but sacred, & blessed in a sort!SW of London, on the road to Croydon and Addiscombe, where TC had often walked or ridden with Lady Ashburton; see 29:116TC to LA, 15 June 1854.—Yours ever T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-EC, [18 Nov.]. MS: NLS 7197.107. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by JWC to MR, [19 Nov.], in which JWC mentions the carpenter and TC’s work on proofs and sending slips to Robson.
div3.head: TC TO EDWARD CHAPMAN

docBody.p: The Paper is ready; and shall be delivered to anybody you send for it. The Printer will need to let me see it in Slips first; as there is yet no Book at the head of it; and foot-note references &c, and perhaps a sentence or two at the end, may require to be introduced.TC could be referring to any of the four essays added at the end of the cheap edn. of Critical and Miscellaneous Essays: “Two Hundred and Fifty Years Ago“ (see TC to HL, 16 Sept.), “The Opera,“ “Project of the National Exhibition of Scottish Portraits,“ and “The Prinzenraub.“ First Proof as soon as you like.

closer.salute: In haste, and great confusion (with Carpenters again in my borders)!—

ps.p: Chelsea Wedy morning

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [19 Nov.]. Addr: Thornhill / Dumfries. PM: London, 20 Nov. 1857; Dumfries, 20 Nov. 1857. MS: NLS 606.469. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:165–68. Quot: Bliss, JWC 269–70; Simpson 125–26; Fielding and Sorensen 228. TC noted later “[20 Novr 1857]”; JWC’s letter was presumably written 19 Nov. and posted in time to catch the night train from Euston to Scotland with the date stamp already set to 20 Nov.
div3.head:
JWC
TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
I had actually miscounted about whose turn it was to write; and am almost glad I did; since it has been the occasion for your writing me such a dear kind letter on “the voluntary principle”! Dont suppose however I should have kept silence much longer even in the mistaken idea you owed me a letter. It had been in my head to write for many days back; but what Mr Carlyle calls “a pressure of things” has made it difficult for me to carry out my own inclinations in any one direction. Thank God I have not to enumerate, among the Things pressing, a cold—that being my bugaboo now— I have been ill with that thing which, for want of a better name, I call “my sickness” and for which I know only one cure to “pack my carpet-bag” (as Dr Russell advised) and rush out into space! But it does not confine me to the house, that sickness; and does not plague anyone but myself— I am used to it (as the pigs to killing) Neither does it prevent me writing letters—only makes my letters like every thing else I do spiritless.— My chief impediment has been that weary Artist
who took the bright idea last spring that he would make a picture of our sitting roomRobert Tait and his painting A Chelsea Interior. John Ruskin, who had been in Scotland with his parents until mid-Oct., presumably saw the picture for the first time in Nov. He gave his judgment in two letters (both undated; one is written on stationery watermarked 1857 and both probably written while advice could still be given to Tait, i.e., before the painting was finished, 5 April 1858). In what is apparently the first letter, he wrote: “I like the little composition very much—but it isn’t quite right—nor can I suggest what would put it right—I can only do as you bid me, & mention the little things which seem to me wrong”; he lists six complaints, including, “Books should always be grave in colour, especially books behind the head of a historian’s wife. Everybody would want to know what you could have been reading”; “Too much insistence on slender waist”; and “People will say Mrs Carlyle is indolent.” In the second letter, he discussed Tait’s faulty perspective: “That if he stands in any point he choose in the room, and tries to get his canvas to hide from his eye all that he has drawn of it, he will find that he cannot do it. He thus violates the first rule of perspective by making his point of station imaginary, or rather impossible. … / The second point to be noted is that even in the supposition of his point of station being possible, I believe the returning distances are not drawn to true scale. … I think he has given the inner room too much recess by an inaccurate use of his measuring line. If he will cut two or three inches off the top and bottom of his picture however it will be very nearly right.” Apparently Tait did not follow his advice; for his note on the perspective, see JWC to MR, 29 March 1858 .—to be “amazingly interesting to Posterity a hundred years hence”— I little knew what I was committing myself to when I let him begin— For the three months before I went to Scotland he came and painted twice a week,—while I was in Scotland he came four times a week; and for the last six weeks he has been overshadowing me like a night-mare every day!! Except when, please God, the fog is so black that he can’t see! These lower rooms are where I have been always used to live at this season; and to keep up fire there, and in the drawing-room as well—besides in Mr C’s study at the top of the house—is a great expence, where coals are seven and twenty shillings a cart load—and is also a great trouble to one servant so I have kept my ground hitherto; always hoping he would get done—but my Heavens! he will make his great “Work of Art” last him into 1860, I begin to think!—a whole day painting at my portfolio! another whole day over my work box and so on! not the minutest object in these three rooms, opening into one another,See opp. above but what is getting itself represented with Vandyke fidelity!Anthony Van Dyck (1599–1641), Flemish painter, court painter to Charles I (1600–1649). And all the while the floor wont be flat for the life of him!JWC apparently made the same complaint to Georgiana Craik who replied, 4 Nov.: “Is it really quite impracticable for Mr Tait to make his floor level?—or could nobody help him? I should be so sorry to think of that picture not getting finished well.”
A Chelsea Interior by Robert Tait (detail)
Courtesy of the National Trust Photographic Library and Michael Boys

I suspect he aims at more than posthumous fame from this picture—hopes perhaps—some admirer of Mr C’s with more money than wit to guide it, may give him a thousand pounds for Mr Cs “Interior” the portraits of Mr C
himself, and Mr C’s wife, and Mr C’s dog inclusive!— The dog is the only member of the family who has reason to be pleased with his likeness as yet!Ruskin concluded his first letter with “That’s all, I think. Nero will be delightful.” See 235.— This will be the second time my dog has appeared in the Exhibition!In the picture Susannah, also by Tait; see 32:132 JWC to MR, [20 April] .— Meanwhile I can’t settle to write when that man is in the way.—
I rush out and ride in omnibuses—I go about the house sorting up—or as the American Ladies say “reconciling things”—

A good deal of that has been needed, in prospect of my two Cousins Maggie and MaryWelsh. to stay here on their road to the Isle of Wight where they mean to pass the Winter—Auchtertool being “too cold”—(or too dull)— I think with astonishment of Mary who can never get up till midday—undertaking such a journey at this season and paying visits all the way—at GlasgowTo their sister Jeannie Chrystal.—at LiverpoolWhere they had lived until their father and older sister died, 1853 (see 28:369 TC to LA, 31 Dec. 1853
), and where their older brother Alexander and his wife, Sophy, still lived.—here—!

I should have greatly preferred one at a time— Mr C is so dreadfully busy just now, and so easily disturbed—that my life is spent in standing between him and the outer world;—and how I am to breast this innundation of it into the very house! how I am to make myself into a human partition between all the interruption and fuss that two young Ladies who have no comprehension of, or sympathy with, hard work, and love of quiet, is more than I know! Then it suddenly flashed on me that I had torn down the head and roof of the spare bed this summer, (which had been spoiled by a cistern overflowing above, and pouring down into the bed in the room beneath)See 30:203 JWC’s Journal, 25 Oct. 1855
.— The room had stood vacant and I had forgotten all about its desolate state— This flashed on me in the night and I couldn’t sleep another wink, for haste to be on foot and out, buying chin[t]z!—lest I should be caught like a foolish house wife, with my spare bed standing naked! Then I had to seek a sempstress—almost as difficult to find as the philosophers stone (for all the “thirty thousand distressed needlewomen”—who cant sew)—and then a carpenter who would not keep me waiting a month—and to shape and do a good deal of hammering myself after all!— Finally today I have the pleasure of seeing the bed rehabilitated— But I am so tired! for the least fuss or hurry plays the deuce with me! I wouldn’t go to bed however till I had thanked you for your letter— I hope to write to you to better purpose soon—
My best love to your Husband Ask him if the fame of pepsine has reached him?—if not I will tell him about it.

ps.p: Every letter I have forgotten to speak of the sweet briar— I should like you to keep it over the winter and send it in spring— It will surely grow with me then!

div3.sourceNote: TC-PC, 23 Nov. MS: Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO PETER CUNNINGHAM

docBody.p: Looking back a year and half, or more, you may perhaps be able to recal a Letter of Lord Hervey’sJohn Hervey (1696–1743; see 23:20TC to JF, [13 April 1848]), Lord Hervey of Ickworth, pamphleteer and memoir writer. (date about 1733 or ’34, to whom addressed I have forgotten; giving a lively sketch of the sublime ennui and hopeless solemn vacancy of George II’s Court, on a certain evening at Windsor),—which was shewn you by Forster, on my part, for the sake of getting some commentary from you on one or two of the Figures introduced. The Commentary, I remember, was kindly afforded: my Copy of the Letter with your commentary on it, and all the proper Apparatus Criticus, was there upon safely reposited here,—no doubt in the best place I cd choose for finding it again when the time shd come.

Well; time has come,—some use possible in that Letter for me now or else no chance of any ever;— —and, for my life, I cannot come upon the trace of it; cannot even find out what Book it was got from: it has gone again, like a little fish caught, into the immeasurable ocean with all its fishes and whales!— It is not in Hervey’s Memoirs of George II;John Hervey, Memoirs of the Reign of George the Second, ed. J. W. Croker (1848); see 23:20TC to JF, [13 April 1848]. nowhere in Walpole;Presumably Horace Walpole (1717–97), 4th earl of Orford, Memoirs of the Reign of King George the Second, ed. Lord Holland, 3 vols. (1846). I cannot the least guess where it is.

If you could discover for me, or perhaps you know witht searching, and could beneficently point out,—I shd soon have another Copy.Cunningham replied, 26 Nov., with information about where to find a printed version of the letter from Lord Hervey to Mrs. Clayton; the original was in the British Museum; it was not included in Frederick. If you cannot, I must say good b’ye to the thing. I was by no means certain I could find use for it in the place where I am; but it is provoking not to be able to decide on clear grounds.

In the name of all rational mortals, I entreat you put a right Index to these your Walpole Volumes;Cunningham replied: “I am getting well on and through … Walpole’s Letters. You will like I think the Index.“ He concluded, “I have a few corrections to give you in your Oliver’s book—I made them the other day in your last Edition. They are tombstone touches about his children.“ The Letters of Horace Walpole, Earl of Orford, ed. Peter Cunningham, 2 vols. (1857); 9 vols. (1857–59).—also I hope you will gather the scattered Notices of
Persons mentioned (footnotes, which one can never find again) into some kind of Alphabetical Order;—and in short are thinking (what has never yet in the least been done in ‘editing’ such Books) that perhaps here and there a rational human being, with serious purposes, may wish to read them humanly,—not bestially, as oxen eat from a hay—now they have got access to, solely for their momentary convenience!— — I design to be into yr Walpole (an excellt clever fellow, in spite of all the balderdash we have heard upon him), so soon as I am out of this dreadful Prussian Bottomless-Pool, where I can hardly swim alive.
Don’t mind the Hervey letter much, or make long search after it. If you report nothing, I will make shift witht it, better or worse shift, who knows which!

ps.p: Frank your brave BrotherFrancis Cunningham (1820–75; ODNB), officer in the Indian Army; later literary ed. of 17th-cent. English playwrights. sent me a little Printed Piece (Sir T. Monroe’s) out of India lately;Liberty of the Press in India: A minute written by Sir T. Munro, thirty-five years ago (Calcutta, 1857). Sir Thomas Munro (1761–1827), b. Glasgow, colonial Indian administrator, brig. gen., gov. of Madras, 1819. Munro warned against introducing freedom of the press in India: “Were the people all our countrymen, I would prefer the utmost freedom of the press; but as they are, nothing could be more dangerous than such freedom. … We are trying an experiment never yet tried in the world; maintaining a foreign dominion by means of a native army, and teaching that army, through a free press, that they ought to expel us and deliver their country. … It is only as regards the natives, that the press can be viewed with apprehension; and it is only when it comes to agitate our native army, that its terrible effects will be felt“ (3, 11). Lord Canning’s suspension of the press in India, 12 June, restricted both the English-language and Indian press by making them apply for licenses that could be withdrawn without notice. The Times and the Examiner opposed the legislation, with the latter arguing, 12 Sept., that Canning should have limited “the liberty of the press in India to publications in the English language. … As to the Indians, they never will be fit to be entrusted with the liberty of the press in their own tongues as long as they stand towards us in the relation of conquered to conquerors.“ whh I was very glad of. Kind regards at home, and to your good Mother especially.Cunningham replied that Jean Cunningham “continues much the same—now ill—now well—& always inactive.“ Ah me!—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-AH[AHO], [23 Nov.]. Addr: Maitlandfield / Haddington. PM: Haddington 24 Nov. 1857 MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:168–71. Quot: Ashton 393.
div3.head: JWC TO AGNES HOWDEN

docBody.p: There’s a good Girl! And thank you!— I choose the present moment for answering; as it is the most improbable I am likely to find! for I have the same sort of defiant pleasure in going in the teeth of probability that I used to have in going in the teeth of a high wind— I am pressed for time, having an appointment two miles off at one o’clock; my attention is distracted by a man painting beside me, and talking;Robert Tait. my nerves are all in a flurry from a recent fright; and Mr Carlyle has just brought me an impossible glove to mend! What more would I have?—

But the fright?—gracious goodness, the fright is worth telling about!— I have a servant whom, during five years that she has been with me, I had never seen in a hurry, or excited, or deprived of her presence of mind.Anne had been at 5 Cheyne Row since Nov. 1853. What then was my astonishment when she rushed into the drawing room last night, with her head tumbled off (as at first it looked to me) and carrying it in her hands!! and crying wildly “Oh Mam! I must go to a Doctor! (scream) my ear my ear! (scream) an animal has run into my ear!!“ She was holding down her head as low as her waist, her cap off, her hair flying, and her hand pressed to her right ear. I sprang forward and pulled her fingers from her ear which was full of blood. “What animal?“ I gasped. “Oh I think it is a black beetle!!“—and the screams went on, and she declared the beetle was “running up into her brain.“ Her ignorance of anatomy was very unfortunate at the moment! I called up Mr Carlyle, for I had lost all presence of mind as well as herself— He took it coolly, as he takes most things; “Syringe it,“ he said; “syringing will bring out any amount of black beetles!!“— There is an apothecary at the bottom of our street;Possibly Hayward Savill Smith, chemist, 47 Cheyne Walk; see also 30:220JWC’s Journal, 21 Nov. 1855. I threw a table cover about her, and told her to run to him; and I begged Mr C to go with her, as it was a dangerous thing for me to go out in the night air. “Go with her?“ he said; “What good could it do my seeing the Beetle taken out of her ear?“— But I had read in a newspaper not long ago of a man killed, by some insect creeping into his ear; and how did I know the apothecary was not an ass, and might spoil her hearing for life with probes and things—if indeed she did not die of it,! or go raving mad, as I should do in her place I thought!

I paced up and down the room for some ten minutes like a wild animal in its cage; then put on a cloak and bonnet and rushed after her—Mr C running after me, to pull me back. When I arrived in the man’s little surgery; I found poor Ann covered with soapsuds, and comparitively calm; and the beetle (it actually was a black beetle) extracted piecemeal (with a probe)— “There might be a leg or so left“ he said; but he would syringe the ear again in the morning— She would not go back to him this morning however; the rushing sound being gone, and the deafness remaining being owing she thinks to the ear being swelled from the rough treatment it got. I was better pleased that this man should not probe any more— If she does not hear with it tomorrow I will send her to a regular Surgeon. Meanwhile I feel as if I had been pounded in a mortar, with the fright of the thing, and have narrowly missed a cold, for I coughed half the night. But that is passed off thank god. I am so afraid of another seven months confinement!

I liked to hear of your Halloween—my ideas of Halloween are all connected with Maitlanfield. I always spent it there as far back as I recollect. Have ducked for apples and burnt nuts in that very kitchen of yours!

If Mrs SkirvingMargaret Lindsay Skirving (1789–1868) of Camptown, Haddington; probably the mother of Robert Scot Skirving (1821–1900; see 13:67JWC to MSC, [late March 1841], and 21:208–9JWC to RSS, 11 May 1847). wants to escape money disaster and all sorts of disaster, she should replace little Ann Camerons poor little white marble tablet in the Churchyard! I could not have confidence in my Fortunes, with such a thing in my cellar.Apparently Ann Cameron’s tombstone was in the cellar of Agnes Howden’s brother; see JWC to AHAHO, [24 Oct.]. Could you?— I should like ill to be the wife of a speculator just now! Mr C has or had some money in America— He doesn’t recollect how much! and doesn’t feel even a natural curiosity what is become of it!!— I have never heard a word out of his head about it except to say once, “I suppose my money will have gone in the crash, and poor ButtlerCharles Butler (1802–97; see 28:314TC to JCA, 18 Nov. 1853, and 32:24532:biographical note), who looked after TC’s investments in the U.S. (the gentleman who invested it for him) will be very sorry!“— Being a Philosopher’s wife has some advantages!— I never think about money myself beyond what serves my daily needs—but if he werent of the same mind I might be made sufficiently uncomfortable about it.
And now good luck to you— Remember me to them all— I owe your sister in lawJessie Howden. a letter, which she shall get some day—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JHS, 29 Nov. Facsimile of MS: Amelia Hutchison Stirling, James Hutchison Stirling, His Life and Work (1912) between 138 and 139. Pbd: Stirling 138–39. James Hutchison Stirling (1820–1909; ODNB; see TC to JHS, 20 May 1840), Scottish philosopher, author of The Secret of Hegel, 2 vols. (1865), a highly influential work in both Scottish and English philosophy.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES HUTCHISON STIRLING

docBody.p: I never in my life was so busy as at present;—and for a good while back and ahead.

If you will come on Tuesday Evg (Tea is at 7½ p.m.), I shall be glad to see you again (nobody but my Wife & I here) for an hour.Stirling recalled his visit, Tues. 1 Dec., and described JWC as “middle-size, pale, with pleasant quiet voice, pleasant smiling eyes, a good face, hair apparently still black—spoke but seldom“ and TC as a “tall, lank figure, hand an extraordinary bunch of fingers, moustache half-grown, black still, whisker round chin grizzled at upper edge, cheek ruddy, but this time hectic-like—flush of vigil, and eye of the lustre and glare of vigil—a general raised look, as of a man with his nervous system in unnatural tension—kind of intellectual animal magnetism, every pore an eye—his hair grey now, still down on brow, brow struck me as both low and narrow. The face small, oval, and pointing towards chin.“ TC was “accustomed now to receive people who only come to see and hear—prone to prose on dreamily about the places he has seen, his impressions, etc.“ Stirling concluded, “General idea of a pair of good simple human beings, of whom rather remarkable that so many people in so many different places should be speaking and writing“ (Stirling139–40).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, [7] Dec. MS: NLS 516.50. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by the opening of Parliament and the 2d attempt to launch the Leviathan.
div3.head:
TC
TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Dear Brother,— I hope you are coursing prosperously southward again, abt this time. I did not want anything in Edinr; John had been on a trip to Edinburgh to settle Arthur Watt for the winter, early Nov. He wrote to TC, 3 Nov., that “[t]he thought of getting into some house of my own is hardly ever out of my mind. Up till August last I had not got quite rid of my Chancery Suit and Ship-owning; I believe it wd hardly have been possible for me to live solitary in any new place even if my affairs had been settled. I do not know that I could stand solitary house-keeping even yet. I have no “society” at all here, but can at least think my own thoughts in peace & freedom. The problem of rushing into new relations at my time of life is not easy to solve, & no one can help me much in the solution of it. If I could see my way I should be quick & resolute enough. Were there any house, in any place not quite foreign to me, to be had, I should probably take it at once & make trial of house-keeping. Sometimes of late I have turned to old Craigenputtk & thought of it as a kind of resource though the place is too remote & solitary. The house, it seems, has many windows & some of the floors sadly decayed—probably from the damp after Thomas Bell’s death—& the new tenant often speaks to Jamie about it, and has spoken to Adamson till he is tired. Jamie says also that he thinks the new tenant might easily be persuaded to live in the smaller house instead of the larger one. All the woods too should be looked after. Now you have no time at all to bestow on thinking of such things, & one cannot well think of them for you without much botheration. … My immature project was to buy Craigenputtock from you, & have it set in order on my own account. Lime, draining, fencing, planting are all wanted; & Jamie says the farm “is dear enough, even in these dear times,” considering the state it has gradually fallen into by exhaustion of old improvements. ‘It is not half so good as it was when Alick was there,’ he says. / / If I were able to try life again amid those stern solitary woods, I shd at least be able to give you a welcome at any time. Houses of a suitable kind are very difficult to find in this country.” Thomas Bell rented Craigenputtoch in 1852 (see 27:48 TC to AC, 18 Feb. 1852
) and d. 1854 (see 29:163 TC to JAC, [ca. 7 Oct. 1854] ). but I wd have written a word that
day, had not an especial whirl of hurries come. I am as ever overwhelmed in big and little confusions; and have no hope left, except (and even that is not a very ecstatic one) the hope of getting this intolerable mass of paper-clippings and paltry marine-stores I.e., rubbish; cf. 18:286 TC to LAAL, 18 Dec. 1844
, and 29:297 TC to JMA, 29 April 1855
. shoved away from me to all eternity!— — Jane keeps afoot; but is always weakish. We have Tait continually painting at a view of the down-stairs room,—I think, for 8 or 10 months back! It is at last growing rather unendurable; and will have to end one way or other.— — This Letter from poor JennyJanet Hanning, writing from Canada. came by the Morning’s post: a poor innocent Letter; bringing nothing but favourable news. You can send it to Jean and the rest of the kindred,—in what order you see best.

Sitting of Parlt is nothing or nearly so to us.The Queen opened both houses of Parliament, Wed., 2 Dec. Printers are fairly into the 2d volume; and they cannot well catch me: May next, May next!— A terrible tussle is going on, launching that Big Ship (Tait always reports),—“exactly the size of Gt George Street Westminster,” I hear!The original launch of the Leviathan (first named the Great Eastern and then later reverting to that name), mainly designed by Isambard Kingdom Brunel (1806– 92
59
; ODNB >), civil engineer, had been planned for 3 Nov. But the ship (13,000 tons, 680 ft. long, and 83 ft. broad) could not be moved, even with the assistance of rams; a second attempt to launch it was made, 7 Dec., but the ship only “moved 108 feet 4 inches at the fore-cradle” (Illustrated London News, 12 Dec. , 582). The launch finally took place, 31 Jan. 1858. For drawings of the ship, see opp above and Illustrated London News (7 Nov. 1857) 457.

figure.p: The Leviathan or Great Eastern steamship

div3.sourceNote: TC-GHL, 7 Dec. MS: McGill Univ. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO G. H. LEWES

docBody.p: The German Translation of that Book is in the hands of Neuberg;Frederick; see TC to EC, 13 Nov. and he has settled about it (with Decker of Berlin) months and years ago. The English Reprint is still open. Tauchnitz of Leipzig applied a long while ago; I set Neuberg to ansr him, “£50 a Volume“; and keep it off me; Neuberg corresponded accordingly, and reported Tauchnitz as prepared to assent: Tauchnitz employed Wms & Norgate, however, who I conjecture advised him to offer Half;—this at any rate they, in his name, not long since, did offer; and it was rejected, and is not likely to be accepted for a good while (I should guess). That is the state of the English Reprint: Vol I lately done, is of 634 pages (if I recollect): Vol II, expected to be ready in May.

I have had such a 14 months as was never appointed me before in this world,—sorrow, darkness and disgust, my daily companions; and no outlook visible except getting a detestable business turned off, or else being driven mad by it.— In a three months more, I hope to be at large again, and capable of seeing those I like.

div3.sourceNote: TC-ET[ETW], 12 Dec. MS: Houghton 65M-181 (7). Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO ELLEN TWISLETON

docBody.p:
I sent the Magazine to its address, yesterday forenoon, according to your order.Ellen Twisleton wrote from Woodlands, Worcestershire, 10 Dec.: “When you have received all that strength against ‘Delusions’—(those things I know you cling to so fondly!—) which Ralph Waldo’s article is calculated to impart, will you be so obliging as to send it to / Mrs Mackintosh / 11. Park Place [The Park Hotel] / St. James’s. / She likes to see her brother-in-law’s harmless poems—so I think we may indulge her—& this twopence (which I enclose) will take it by post.“ The article was probably Emerson, “Illusions,“ Atlantic Monthly 1, no. 1 (Nov. 1857): 58–62. Mrs. Mackintosh is Mary, b. Appleton, m. to Robert James Mackintosh (1805–1864; see 30:224JWC’s Journal, 25 Nov. 1855); her brother-in-law was Henry Wadsworth Longfellow (1807–82), m. to her sister Fanny (d. 1861), whose poem “The Mourning Veil“ was in the same issue of Atlantic Monthly (1: 63). There are several amusing Articles in it (rather weak, most of them, especially the English one whh heads off);The Nov. issue of Atlantic Monthly began with an obituary of Douglas Jerrold (1803–57; ODNB), who had d. 8 June 1857; see 32:165TC to JAC, 11 June. but nothing that rises above
commonplace except Emerson,—who is getting very wire-drawn quaint and sceptical, but has always something beautifully human in him; extremely distinguishable amid the apehoods that current.

You and the Goodman must appoint your own Evg, and come down to us,—locomotion not being quite our forte at present. However, the Wife (who returns your many regards)Ellen Twisleton had written that they were to be in London for two days in about a week’s time: “[T]hen ‘shall we shoot you, or will you Shoot us?’—i.e. may we come one evening to tea with you, or will you come one evening to tea with us? either way the favour will be highly esteemed by your humble servant my husband, and your tedious correspondent myself. / Please give my best love to your dear wife.“ is still on foot, for whh we ought to be thankful in comparison.
I am, as usual, plunging along on the treadmill; continuing my sad function, till I end it or it end me. Yours always sincerely / T. Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 13 Dec. Addr: Steamboat Pier / Battersea Bridge. MS: Huntington Lib. Quot: Larkin, BQR 44.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Would you be so good as call on Monday,The next day. in passing. I want you to take up some Ms. to Robson; also to leave with him the Title of yr two German sets of Maps for a footnote,—(properly nothing but the year & place of “Stieler“Adolf Stieler (1775–1836; see 32:22TC to JN, 31 Oct. 1856); TC refers to his Deutschland as an “excellent Map in 25 Pieces“ (Works 14:352). is wanted for said footnote: but they need that at once,—if indeed at all).

The Summary of Vol IV seems to be first-rate.Of Critical and Miscellaneous Essays; it had been advertised as ready for 4 Dec., Athenaeum 28 Nov. (see 32:218Chapman & Hall’s Advertisements). Larkin recalled: “I was much pleased at the time with these few emphatic words, for the summary referred to actually extended to seventeen pages; nor could I honestly condense it into less. The prescribed limit … was ‘seven or eight pages at the outside’; but I never could manage it, without leaving out much which I felt really ought to be indicated. … I ought to say that, after the first index and summary of Sterling [see 32:83TC to HL, 30 Jan.], Carlyle never once saw any of them until they were in print, and, I believe (excepting ‘Sartor’. . . ), never once altered, or suggested the altering of a word; so that the responsibility of what I wrote rested entirely with me“ (Larkin, BQR 44–45). Yours ever truly

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, [20] Dec. MS: NLS 516.49. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by Maggie and Mary Welsh’s visit until “Thursday next” and by TC to JAC, 28 Dec. , where they had left “Thursday last” [24 Dec.].
div3.head:
TC
TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Nothing is wrong with us; don’t be under apprehension Jane goes about; seems rather fresher if anything lately: indeed I suspect the critical time has not yet come,—till the jany or feby cold days arrive. We have never yet had the least touch of frost; once or twice, as this morning, perhaps a half-visible touch of rime; but it soon goes away again in rain or something soft: occasionally the days are almost beautiful in the middle part of them,—almost too good for December weather.

Jane’s chief suffering at present is the burden of two innocent young Auchtertool Damsels, “Maggy” and “Mary”;Welsh. who are here on their road to the Isle of Wight; Mary, sickly for a long while past, having been ordered thither for a better climate in the cold season. They do not stay above 10 days, “to see London by the road,”—only till Thursday next;—and do me very little mischief; only Jane, who takes a heavy handful of them, and is not fit for any burden at all but her own, wishes it were well done. The Miss Mary has been always of languid turn; took decided disease of the liver some years ago; very dangerously ill at one time but now much better;—is likely to continue dragging about; and cannot well expect to be, what she never was, in lively health. I remember her a little child always too late at breakfast, in Liverpool;See 18:233 JWC to GEJ, [7 Oct. 1844] . and I used to call her “the Morning Star,” poor little creature. There is some Fife neighbourLiddells or Liddles, see 31:163 JWC to TC, [8 Aug. 1856] , 190 JWC to TC, [23 Aug. 1856] , and TC to JAC, 28 Dec.
in the Isle of Wight; and they are likely to be better off for a couple of months there than in the solitude of Auchtertool.

You shd bid your Jim write to John with great frankness, explaining so far as is possible what he is in wish for, if not in hope of:See TC to JCA, 2 Nov.
I always think there is some clear feasibility of getting him a settlement in Liverpool, had one time to try fairly;—and the Dr at present is the only one of us that has his hands quite free for making application in such a matter. I believe I owe him a Letter, ever since his last Glasgow excursion: I have always a kind of expectation he is coming up hither abt this season; but he does not come, or positively hold out probability in any direction.

That of the Rob-Haining American Snob ‘with the red beard, is very Hanningish: Perhaps a relative of Robert Hanning from N. America, otherwise unidentified.
but it is no great matter either; we will manage with the red beard, “I guess,” if it ever appear in these parts.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady S[LST], [ca. 20 Dec.]. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd. Dated during the visit of Maggie and Mary Welsh, JWC’s “Northeren cousins“; they left, 24 Dec.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY STANLEY

docBody.p:
Thanks, dear Lady Stanley, for the “glorious opportunity“ offered us! I, for one, hoped to avail myself of it; but Mr C’s friends “the Destinies“ willed
otherwise—interfered in the shape of some NortherenThus in MS. Cousins who exhausted my strength, still very small, before the appointed hour.

As for my Husband to his shame, or his praise be it spoken, he professed himself more disposed for a call “when you were alone“ than when “mixed up with “the Georges.“Unidentified; perhaps members of the Prussian royal family on the guest list for the marriage, 25 Jan., of Victoria, the princess royal, and Crown Prince Friedrich Wilhelm of Prussia (see TC to JAC, 28 Jan. 1858); Lord Stanley wrote to Lady Stanley, 17 Dec., that there were “no end of Prussian Princes … coming over“ (Nancy Mitford, ed., The Stanleys of Alderley [1968] 166).
docBody.name: Jane Carlyle

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC, [21 Dec.]. MS: NLS Acc. 7988. Hitherto unpbd. Conjecturally dated in 1857, the Monday before TC to JAC, 28 Dec., when TC asks John to tell James and Isabella that the meal they have sent “proves excellent.“
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE

docBody.p: Dear James,— The meal-barrel has arrived this moment, just as I am on the road to walk out. All is safe and right, externally; how the chickens &c prove to have stood such negligence of time, I will explain more at large tomorrow. Jane has been croaking doubly ever since yr Letter came. Till tomorrow adieu.

div3.sourceNote: TC-HL, 22 Dec. MS: Huntington Lib. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY LARKIN

docBody.p: Would you be so good as call again, and tell Mr Robson that I am well aware of the “irregular“ character of the Ms. (probably the most irregular he ever had to do with!)—but that on the whole he must contrive to give me some guess of it. His guess will be better than mine; and that latter (a very dark rule indeed) is all I have to go by at present!—

If Mr LeveyGeorge Levey of Robson, Levey & Franklyn, 23 Gt. New St. and Fetter Lane. will take the thing in hand, and form his best opinion, witht telling anybody; and then if Mr Robson will do the like,—I should suppose the mean of those two computations would be near the truth. On the whole I
must form some kind of notion; and how am I to do it!— Tell them to do their best for me; and thereby I shall at least be much nearer the fact than at present.

I have no doubt the Sartor is considerably illuminated by your faithful labour upon it.See TC to HL, 8 Jan. 1858. I will with great pleasure read a Proofsheet (and send you my remarks) if you can get me one in time.
If I knew the extent of that Ms., I shd now go ahead for the conclusion of this First Part of Frh. whh will be a deliverance indeed, to the weary human soul!—
We hope to see you on some occasion before long.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 23 Dec. Addr: 25. Oakley Villas / Adelaide Road / Haverstock Hill. MS: NLS 552.149. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p: I wish you wd get me some more Paper,—same as this Note: white colour wd not be unwelcome; but beware of changes! This takes the ink, has no vile fur upon it (as the last “improvement“ of the Big Sheets had); it will be safer to hold strait by this.

I have been dreadfully stupid and weak for the last ten days; shuddering to begin “Book X,“The last book of vol. 2 of Frederick; see TC to EC, 25 Oct.—till I am grown quite miserable again, and obliged to do it.

I want some little thing, possibly attainable in the Museum, about old Kur-Pfalz and the specific dates &c of his negociations and procedures in the Sulzbach-Prussia matter in 1737, 1738. Also (out of some Dictionary or the like) a precise fact or two concerning Luiscius, Fredh Wm’s minister at the Hague who was concerned in those same Kur-Pflaz transactions;For Kur-Pfalz [elector of the Palatinate] Karl Philip and Luiscius, see Works 14:217–21. and went out of his wits in consequence, and (twice) almost out of the world: he is the “Lucius,“ whom Voltaire mentions; the unfortunate ‘who se coupe la gorge avec le seul rasoir qu’il eût [cut his throat with the only razor he had],—clearly an over-statement as to his stock of rasors!

There is also something to be done abt Berlin Prints;—Mr Tait to be asked, in the first place, if he will do me a Photogrph of the Fredh Wm Print
I have here (I mean my own Little one, whh cd then go to Berlin on a certain errand.No closing bracket. TC presumably wants to send the photograph to Berlin for engraving; see TC to EC, 23 Dec. The frontispiece to vol. 2 was of Friedrich Wilhelm; see TC to EC, 13 Nov.
If we hear nothing, I will look for you on Sunday Evg.

p.name: T. Carlyle
p.note: Arthur Helps wrote, 22 Dec., that TC had been invited to join the committee of the Public Health Dept.: “This Committee will consist of very eminent Men in many ways—there will be 6 or 7 of the first surgeons & physicians 3 engineers—4 or 5 political men such as Ld Stanley, Goderich, Mr Cowper, &c—men of science such as Owen, Faraday—resolute Sanitarians such as Chadwick—a few men of letters, who have shown interest in the subject. / Whether you accept this invitation or not, I think you would have been pleased to see the way in which your name was received—as that of a man who had already done good service. … / If you were to ask me the use of the thing—I shd say it would be in collecting & sifting information, & in occasionally administering some stimulus to the government. These matters go on being managed as badly as possible.“ Lord Stanley; Lord Goderich; William Cowper (1811–88; ODNB), politician, M.P. for Hertford, 1835–63, pres. of Board of Health, 1855, vice pres. of committee of Council on Education, 1857–58; Richard Owen; Michael Faraday (1791–1867; ODNB; see TC to JWI, 3 Feb. 1837), scientist; Edwin Chadwick (1800–1890; ODNB; see TC-CP, 7 June 1853), sanitary reformer.

div3.sourceNote: TC-EC, 23 Dec. MS: Yale. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO EDWARD CHAPMAN

docBody.p: Unless it is altogether inconvenient, will you now, to keep the Christmas Hawks out of my eyes, send me the Draught you spoke.Unexplained, unless connected to the letter of E. C. Hilman or E. Chilman of the Joint Stock Bank, 69 Pall Mall, 9 Dec., which pointed out that TC’s account appeared to be overdrawn by £3 13s. 2d. Crossed, it will come by the Post; and I will return a receipt.

Holl was here the other day; had seen the Picture; wished to have it beside him;—and has, this morning (if the Post was faithful) got Lord A.’s permission to come or send for it. If he is to do (as I suppose it will be he) the Frontce to Vol 2d too,See TC to EC, 13 Nov. I hope you will keep him to his work,—that there be no waiting in the end.

I have got some Berlin Prints; but no King (Father) I like so well as one I have already here;—there is a much better QueenPresumably TC is referring to Frederick’s mother, Sophie Dorothee (1687–1767). There is no portrait of her or of Frederick’s wife, Elisabeth Christine (1715–97), princess of Brunswick-Bevern, in the first 2 vols. of Frederick. but she is 10 years too old
for us. I am about trying Berlin again by a new ethod. You and Holl shall hear when the Result arrives.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, 25 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 7864. Pbd: Froude, LM 2:342–43. “Printing of Friedrich, first two volumes, now well advanced. Christmas was spent among the most refractory set of proof sheets I expect in this world“ (TC’s headnote in LM).
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.dateline: 5 Cheyne Row Chelsea / Xmas day [25 December 1857]
docBody.p: I understood that your Brother would write himself today, to announce the safe arrival of your box—the contents of which were exhibited to him in succession last night, (When it came to the goose, carried in on my arms, like a strange new kind of Baby (with that belly-band about it!) he burst into such a laugh! “That fellow I think has got his quietus“Cf. Hamlet 3.1. (he said—) But now he has just come down and is off for his ride, and when I asked; “had he written to Mary“? he exclaimed wildly that he had “fifteen hours of the most awful work, of correcting proofs a-head of him—that I who had nothing to do should have written to Mary“— With all the pleasure in life! had I known in time; instead of within just half an hour of post time—from which is to be subtracted ten minutes for putting on my things and running to the post office!— But better a line than no letter at all till tomorrow—you thinking the while that all those blessed birds may be coming to harm—from being too long on the road! no my Dear! one “Chuka“ is boiling at this moment for the masters dinner (I dine on anything at two o’clock; not being up to waiting for Mr C’s six or seven o clock dinners)— But I had one of the eggs to my breakfast and it was the very best and biggest I ever eat in my life!—there were only two broken and not wasted even these: I lifted up the yokes which lay quite round and whole in a spoon! (for puddings)—
I wish I had begun in time for I had plenty of things to say—but I must keep for this time to mere acknowlegement of your present—another day I may tell you the rest Yours ever affectionately

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 28 Dec. MS: NLS 525.32. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:304.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I have been too long in writing; but there really is no limit to the hurry and confusion I am kept in here;—very weak and spirit less, too, for most part;—and in fact there was nothing passing whh much called me out into writing.

Your tour to the North wd be a pleasant break in the stillness of yr Scots-brig life: but probably you wd be glad to get back again into quiet; for I suppose you have got used to it by this time, and may prefer the comparative absence from annoyance to any satisfaction you could get from variety or society. You have no mention of a tour this way, of late? It is about a year since you have not seen London nor London you:—but indeed there is but little to invite a quiet soul to, in this more and more chaotic element.

We had the two Miss Welshes from Auchtertool for an eight days lately. They were bound for the Isle of Wight, whither the Younger had been ordered for chance of benefit by the “better air.“ She is not well, poor thing; but I do not fancy better air will do much for her: change of scene, and interruption to the monotony of indolent ennui may perhaps be beneficial for the time,—and that may have been what the Dr. really meant by his order.Dr. James Dewar; see JWC to TC, [3 Aug.].— The poor Lasses are very innocent amiable creatures: they did me no ill while here; but were a little hard upon “Cousin,“ who is not fit for much supervision and House-generalship in her present weak state. They went off, Thursday last,—forgetting only a “hamper“ here;—they got safe to Ventnor,Resort town, Isle of Wight; see 24:93TC to JWC, 3 July 1849. John Sterling d. there; see 18:214–15TC to JAC, 20 Sept. 1844. to certain Liddells who are there, with whom they are to stay for a week till they get lodgings of their own.

We seem about to get into frost, our first of this season; and I am anxious about my poor Helpmate in regard to that. She is very feckless; tho’ full of spirit, when she can get the least chance; sleep is still a scarcity; and cold temperature seems to tell on her at once.— I am actually getting into the last “Book“ of my Ms. for this bout! Nothing can come more ungainly than every bit of that unfortunate work has done; no end to difficulty, to despicable fash, abt the despicable enterprise: but, by Heaven’s help, there begins to be daylight thro’ this First Part of it,—as above said. The Printer is nearly thro Book I of Vol II; and he cannot now catch me, tho’ marching with uncommon steadiness. “By the end of May,“ I hope to be safe in some rustic solitude, “upon milk diet,“ and in blessed depth of “silence,“ for an unlimited period!— You can tell Jamie and Isabella, the meal proves excellent; and gives
one a morsel of innocent supper every night; a thing to be reckoned among the blessings of the 24 hours. We were busy on the Ham too (for which, I hope, Jane duly thanked the kind donors!),—when a body of eggs &c from the Gill suspended that attack for some time. We are much indebted for kind remembrances from those who love us tho’ hidden from them.

All mortals are tumbling about, in a state of drunken Saturnalia delirium or quasi-delirium, according to their various sorts: a very strange method of “thanking God for sending them a Redeemer“;—a set singularly worth “redeeming,“ too, you wd say! I spent Xmas and the two days following in grim contention, all day each time, with the most refractory set of Proofsheets I expect in this Work;— —tho sternly done. Tait has finished his “Picture“ of the Interior; at least he has taken it away,—thank Heaven. “Leviathan“ cannot be launched at all!See TC to JAC, [7] Dec. We think of going to see it some day for a holiday,—would, but could we?— Sad remembrance of another XmasTheir mother’s death, 25 Dec. 1853; see 28:349TC to JWC, 25 Dec. 1853. present to me, also, at all moments. Which made a strange combination, peculiarly tragic when I had time to see it from the distance;—like a man set to whittle cherrystones and toy boxes in the Valley of the Shadow of Death!— Adieu dear Brother: my sheet is done. Write to me; give my love & regards that do not decay to the Friends you are among. T. Carlyle

Ruskin sent me two “Lectures,“ delivered in Manchester:The Political Economy of Art: being the Substance (with Additions) of Two Lectures delivered at Manchester, July 10 and 13, 1857. Ruskin advocated increased public funding for the preservation of ancient buildings and the establishment of higher standards of public education in art and architecture.
